column4: Im trying to run this command: the /proc/asound/card0/pcm0p/oss file, but the permissions are wrong. I change the permissions and edit it, but when I reboot the oss file gets set back to default with nothing in it and no write permissions for anyone. How can I fix this?
Sorry, im trying to edit that file
I am not so sure you should _edit_ that file. It is a virtual file, not a real file. it is a settings file.
I need to edit it to get sound to work in a game.
no, you don't, you need to _write_ to it.
consider reading the OSS compatibility section of http://tinyurl.com/4ogk2
Yes, but everytime i reboot it gets set back to read only
it is a virtual file, not a real file. It is under '/proc'.
Well how do I get my sound to work with this file?
you 'echo' the value to the file in an initialization script.
consider reading the OSS compatibility section of http://tinyurl.com/4ogk2
I do use the echo command, but I get permission denied
you have to do it as 'root'.
I use sudo, too. Which startup script do you recommend?
there is a subtle difficulty with 'sudo' and redirection... if you say 'sudo echo xxxx > yyy', the file "yyy" is opened by the current shell, not by 'sudo'.
try 'sudo bash' and then 'echo .....' at the prompt that appears.
Is there a config file I may edit to get this command to run at startup?
